subject: Re: assertEqual and assertSame
msgSnippet: ... assertEqual(a, b) more or less checks a.equals(b) assertSame(a, b) checks a == b So assertEqual checks that two objects are logically identical (according
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "cute4gerbil" <cute4gerbil@y...> wrote:
> Hi,
> can anyone tell me what is the different between the use of
> assertEqual and assertSame.
>
> What i know is that assertEqual is "Asserts that two objects are
> equal. If they are not an AssertionFailedError is thrown."
>
> And assertSame is "Asserts that two objects refer to the same object.
> If they are not an AssertionFailedError is thrown."
>
> can u give me a example how they are being used differently.
>
> Thank =)

assertEqual(a, b) more or less checks a.equals(b)
assertSame(a, b) checks a == b

So assertEqual checks that two objects are logically identical
(according to that class's notion of equality); assertSame checks that
two references popint to the same exact object.

So, if you do this:

String s1 = "abc";
String s2 = s1;
assertEqual(s1, s2); // true, test passes
assertSame(s1, s2); // also true, test passes

However:

String s1 = "abc";
String s2 = "abc";
assertEqual(s1, s2); // true, test passes
assertSame(s1, s2); // false, test fails!

In practice you would use assertEqual most of the time but use
assertSame if you want to check things like caching mechanisms that
should always return the same instance of a given object, like:

MyObject o1 = getFromCache("key");
MyObject o2 = getFromCache("key");
assertSame(o1, o2);

I hope this helps.

Bruno
